subject: RE: [junit] How to record test results in XML format
msgSnippet: Hi All, I have optional.jar file in my ANT_HOME/lib directory. I am getting the class not found. Following below is the error message: error
messageBody:
Hi All,

I have optional.jar file in my ANT_HOME/lib directory.

I am getting the class not found. Following below is
the error message:

error "/users/test/build.xml:2: taskdef class
com.proj.test.autotest.AutotestHarness cannot be found

Here is my code snippet:

<project name="Autotest" default="run">
<!-- taskdef name="myrun"
classname="com.proj.test.autotest.AutotestHarness" -->
<classpath>
<pathelement
location="/vobs/autotest/portal_kernel/lib/junit.jar"
/>
<pathelement
location="/ausp3/jakarta-ant-1.4.1/lib/optional.jar"
/>
</classpath>
</taskdef>

<target name="run">
<junit printsummary="true">
<test
name="com.proj.test.autotest.AutotestHarness"
outfile="results">
<formatter type="xml" />
</test>
</junit>
</target>

</project>


Please help me in resolving this issue.

Note: I am using Jbuilder to build my class file then
I am using ANT to run the class and output the result
in XML format.

Thanks in Advance!!!!

Regards,
Syed.



--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
wrote:
> Likely you do not have Ant's "optional.jar" in the
> CLASSPATH when
> running Ant. Please refer to the Ant documentation
> for details.
>
> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
>
> On 2002-07-09 at 14:23 syed Anwaruddin wrote:
>
> >Hi Jason,
> >
> >Thanks for your help!!!!
> >
> >When I execute sample build.xml, I am getting the
> >following error:
> >"Unexpected element "junit"
> >
> >Following below is the sample code:
> ><project name="Autotest" default="test">
> > <target name="run" />
> > <junit printsummary="true" >
> > <test
> >name="com.test.tc.autotest.checkClass"
> >outfile="results">
> > <formatter type="xml" />
> > </test>
> > </junit>
> >
> ></project>
> >
> >Please let me know where I am wrong.
> >
> >Thanks & Regards,
> >Syed.
> >
> >
> >
> >--- Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
> >> go to http://jakarta.apache.org/ant
> >> download a binary (which includes documentation)
> >> set up your build script (read the documentation)
> >> run it (read the documentation)
> >>
> >> A simple build script may be (you'll want to
> replace
> >> all the hardcoded
> >> paths to properties):
> >>
> >> <project name="MyProject" default="tests">
> >> <path id="somePath">
> >> <pathelement location="lib/sub1/some1.jar"/>
> >> <pathelement location="lib/sub2/some2.jar"/>
> >> <pathelement location="lib/sub3/some3.jar"/>
> >> </path>
> >>
> >> <target name="tests" depends="build">
> >> <junit printsummary="yes" haltonfailure="no">
> >> <classpath refid="somePath"/>
> >>
> >> <formatter type="xml"/>
> >>
> >> <batchtest fork="yes" todir="reports">
> >> <fileset dir="build"/>
> >> </batchtest>
> >> </junit>
> >>
> >> <junitreport todir="reports">
> >> <fileset dir="reports">
> >> <include name="TEST-*.xml"/>
> >> </fileset>
> >> <report format="frames" todir="reports"/>
> >> </junitreport>
> >> </target>
> >>
> >> <target name="build">
> >> <javac
> >> srcdir="src"
> >> destdir="build">
> >> <classpath refid="somePath"/>
> >> </javac>
> >> </target>
> >> </project>
> >> On Tue, 2002-07-09 at 09:37, syed Anwaruddin
> wrote:
> >> Hi Scott,
> >>
> >> Thanks for the immediate reply!!!
> >>
> >> You mean, I need to install ANT module???
> >> I am very new to this. Please mail me one example
> OR
> >> atleast let me know where can I find the
> >> documentation
> >> for this.
> >>
> >> Thanks and Regards,
> >> Syed.
> >>
> >>
> >> --- Scott Stirling <scottstirling@...> wrote:
> >> > Easiest way to do it is use the JUnit tasks
> >> (<junit>
> >> > and <batchtest>) in
> >> > Ant, which will automatically output results in
> >> XML
> >> > format if you tell
> >> > them to. Then use <junitreport> to
> automatically
> >> > transform the XML into
> >> > a nice framed HTML report.
> >> >
> >> > Scott Stirling
> >> >
> >> > > -----Original Message-----
> >> > > From: s_thoda [mailto:s_thoda@...]
> >> > > Sent: Monday, July 08, 2002 5:28 PM
> >> > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> >> > > Subject: [junit] How to record test results
> in
> >> XML
> >> > format
> >> > >
> >> > >
> >> > > Hi All,
> >> > >
> >> > > We have an Autotest suit using Junit in my
> >> > project. We were
> >> > > generating .txt files to record all the test
> >> > results. I want to use
> >> > > XML for recording all the autotest results.
> >> Please
> >> > advice me on how
> >> > > to go about this.
> >> >
> >> >
> >> >
> >> >
> >>
> >>
> >>
